architects.name: Imhotep
architects.description: Imhotep is considered the first architect in history and a renowned physician. He was also the chief advisor to the pharaoh Djoser.
notable_buildings: Step Pyramid of Djoser at Saqqara

architects.name: Senenmut
architects.description: Senenmut was a notable architect during the reign of Queen Hatshepsut. He was also a high-ranking official in the royal court.
notable_buildings: Temple of Hatshepsut at Deir el-Bahri

architects.name: Hemiunu
architects.description: Hemiunu was an architect and a vizier during the reign of pharaoh Khufu. He is believed to have designed the Great Pyramid of Giza.

style.description: Ancient Egyptian architecture is the architecture of the ancient Egyptians, who built many of the most impressive and enduring monuments in the world. It includes temples, tombs, pyramids, obelisks, and other structures.
characteristics: Stylized depictions of gods and pharaohs

Ancient Egyptian.terms: pyramids, temples, tombs, monumental, grandiose, ornate, columns, hieroglyphics, sandstone, limestone, monumentalism, symmetry, vast, elaborate, impressive.

architects.name: Phidias
architects.description: A celebrated sculptor, architect, and master builder who worked primarily in Athens. He is best known for his monumental statues and reliefs, including the statue of Athena Parthenos in the Parthenon.

architects.name: Iktinos
architects.description: A Greek architect who designed the Parthenon together with Callicrates. Although very little is known about his life, Iktinos' contribution to the Parthenon is considered one of the finest examples of classical Greek architecture.

architects.name: Mnesicles
architects.description: A notable Greek architect who was responsible for the design of the Propylaea, the gateway to the Acropolis. Mnesicles' was known for his use of curved walls and his ability to create dramatic and imposing entrances to important buildings.

architects.name: Callicrates
architects.description: One of the two main architects who designed the Parthenon

style.description: Greek Classical architecture is characterized by its simplicity, harmony, and order. Buildings were designed to be functional and aesthetically pleasing, with a focus on proportion and balance. The style is known for its use of columns, capitals, and friezes, as well as pediments, cornices, and entablatures. The Greek Classical style influenced architecture throughout Europe and continues to be a major influence in modern architecture.
characteristics: Use of columns, capitals, and friezes

Ancient Greek.terms: marble columns, symmetrical design, Doric order, Ionic order, pediments, entablatures, elegant proportions, eternal beauty, harmonious balance, mythological sculptures, grandeur, mathematical precision, white purity, timeless style

architects.name: Vitruvius
architects.description: Ancient Roman writer, architect and engineer

architects.name: Apollodorus of Damascus
architects.description: Greek-roman architect
architects.notable_buildings: Trajan's Column, Market of Trajan, Hadrian's Wall

architects.name: Marcus Vitruvius Pollio
architects.description: Roman writer, architect, and engineer

style.description: Roman Classical architecture is a style that emerged in ancient Rome and was heavily influenced by Ancient Greek architecture. It is characterized by its use of classical orders, such as the Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian, as well as its use of arches, vaults, and domes. The architecture was grand and impressive, with many buildings featuring large colonnades and intricate details.

Ancient Roman.terms: Columns, symmetrical, pediments, arches, vaults, Doric, Ionic, Corinthian, elegant, influential, enduring.

architects.name: Anthemius of Tralles
architects.description: A mathematician and architect famous for designing the Hagia Sophia.

architects.name: Isidore of Miletus
architects.description: An architect known for designing the Hagia Sophia.

architects.name: Sedulius
architects.description: An architect and theologian who designed several churches in Constantinople.
notable_buildings: Basilica of St. John the Apostle

style.description: Byzantine architecture refers to the architectural style developed during the Byzantine Empire period, characterized by a combination of Roman, Greek, and Eastern influences. It is known for its use of intricate mosaics, domes, and vaulted ceilings.
examples: Church of the Holy Apostles, Thessaloniki
Church of St. John the Evangelist, Ravenna

Byzantine.terms: dome, mosaic, intricate, opulent, grand, basilica, vault, ornate, complex, timeless.

architects.name: William of Normandy
architects.description: Norman architect who brought the Romanesque style to England after the Norman Conquest

architects.name: Abbot Suger
architects.description: French statesman and architect who developed the Gothic style from Romanesque architecture

architects.name: Robert de Luzarches
architects.description: French architect and member of the team that designed the Notre Dame Cathedral, one of the most famous examples of Romanesque architecture

style.description: Romanesque architecture is a style of architecture that emerged in Europe in the Middle Ages. It is characterized by rounded arches, barrel and groin vaults, and thick walls. Romanesque architecture was initially used for churches, monasteries, and castles.

Romanesque.terms: rounded arches, sturdy pillars, thick walls, decorative carvings, symmetrical design, simplistic aesthetic

architects.name: Abbot Suger
architects.description: Considered the father of Gothic architecture

architects.name: Peter Parler
architects.description: Master builder of St. Vitus Cathedral in Prague

architects.name: Gothic Architecture
architects.description: A style of architecture that flourished during the high and late medieval period

style.description: Gothic architecture is a style of architecture that originated in France in the 12th century and continued in Europe until the 16th century. It is characterized by its pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses, which allowed for taller and more intricate structures than earlier Romanesque architecture. Gothic architecture was used predominantly for churches, cathedrals, and civic buildings.

Gothic.terms: Gothic architecture: pointed arches, ribbed vaults, flying buttresses, ornate decoration, verticality, dramatic light and shade, towering spires, intricate tracery, majestic cathedrals.

architects.name: Filippo Brunelleschi
architects.description: Considered the founding father of Renaissance architecture, Brunelleschi was an architect, engineer, and designer. He played a key role in the development of perspective and was known for his use of classical elements in his designs.

architects.name: Leon Battista Alberti
architects.description: Alberti was an Italian humanist, architect, and poet. He is considered a pioneer in the field of architecture and played a key role in the revival of classical architecture in the Renaissance period.

architects.name: Andrea Palladio
architects.description: A distinguished architect who dominated Venetian architecture for many years, Palladio was known for his use of classical elements such as columns, pediments, and domes. His designs were characterized by symmetry, simplicity, and proportion.

style.description: An architectural style that emerged in Italy in the 14th century and spread throughout Europe, characterized by a revival of classical forms and a focus on symmetry, proportion, and harmony.
characteristics: Use of classical orders (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian)
Emphasis on mathematical proportion and harmony
Decorative elements such as pilasters, pediments, and cornices
Use of domes, columns, and arcades
Integration of sculpture and painting into architectural compositions
examples: St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City

Renaissance.terms: buildings, structures, domes, arches, columns, symmetry, proportion, harmony elegant, extravagant, ornate, classical, monumental, grand, sophisticated

architects.name: Francesco Borromini
architects.description: A master of Baroque architecture and sculpture, known for his creative, free-form style and for his innovative use of light and shadow.

architects.name: Gian Lorenzo Bernini
architects.description: An architect, sculptor, and painter who helped to define the Baroque style in Rome and throughout Europe.

architects.name: Johann Bernhard Fischer von Erlach
architects.description: An influential Austrian Baroque architect, who designed buildings in both Vienna and Salzburg.

style.description: Architectural style characterized by opulence, dynamism, and drama
characteristics: Dramatic use of light and shade

Baroque.terms: ornate, extravagant architecture characterized by ornamental detail, curved lines, grandeur, drama, opulence, drama, elaborate ornamentation

architects.name: Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli
architects.description: Rococo architect who worked mainly in Russia.

architects.name: Jean-Baptiste Pigalle
architects.description: French sculptor and architect who worked in the Rococo style.

architects.name: Bartolomeo Rastrelli
architects.description: Italian architect who worked in the Russian Empire.

style.description: Rococo architecture is characterized by its elaborate decoration, asymmetrical designs, and emphasis on ornamentation. It is often associated with the aristocracy and was popular in Europe during the mid-18th century to early 19th century.
characteristics: Extravagant use of gold and pastel colors

Rococo.terms: decorative, ornate, asymmetrical, curvaceous, delicate, elegance, excess, lavishness, theatricality playful, whimsical, feminine, light-hearted, ostentatious, baroque-esque, indulgent, fanciful, opulent.

architects.name: Andrea Palladio
architects.description: Considered one of the most influential architects in Western architecture history, known for his rigorous design and proportion theories.

architects.name: Robert Adam
architects.description: Famous for his elegant, decorative, and refined designs, Adam was one of the key figures of the Georgian era.

architects.name: Thomas Jefferson
architects.description: An American Founding Father, Jefferson was also a skilled architect and archaeologist who contributed to the development of the neoclassical style in the United States.

style.description: A revival of classical architecture that emerged in the 18th century characterized by symmetry, order, and simplicity. It was a reaction against the elaborate, ornate, and irregular Baroque and Rococo styles.
characteristics: Use of columns, triangular pediments, and domes
Use of mathematical proportions and ratios
examples: The White House in Washington D.C.
The Royal Palace of Caserta in Italy

Neoclassical.terms: classical forms, symmetry, columns, domes, pediments, porticos, arches, friezes, balustrades simple, elegant, restrained, balanced, ordered, harmonious, timeless

architects.name: John Nash
architects.description: John Nash was an English architect responsible for many important buildings in Georgian and Regency style.

architects.name: Robert Adam
architects.description: Robert Adam was a Scottish neoclassical architect, interior designer and furniture designer.

architects.name: James Wyatt
architects.description: James Wyatt was an English architect, a rival of Robert Adam, who worked in the neoclassical style and the Gothic Revival.

style.description: Georgian architecture is a style that emerged in Britain during the reign of George I in 1714 and continued until 1830 during the reign of George IV. It is characterized by a heightened interest in classical forms and ornamentation.
characteristics: Central entrances with fanlights and sidelights
examples: St. Paul's Parish Church in Antigua and Barbuda
The Customs House in Dublin, Ireland
City Hall in Savannah, Georgia, USA

Georgian.terms: style, period, tradition, building, design, symmetry, proportions, elegance, refinement, ornamentation, façade, porticos, cornices, pediments, fenestration, balconies, chimneys, mansard roofs, brick, stone. neoclassical, grand, graceful, imposing, dignified, balanced, harmonious, proportional, intricate, detailed, ornate, decorative, iconic, timeless, prestigious, stately, elegant.

architects.name: Augustus Pugin
architects.description: Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin was an English architect and design reformer who is credited with popularising the Gothic Revival style in architecture.

architects.name: Eduardo VII
architects.description: King Edward VII was a monarch known for his interest in art, fashion, and architecture. He was a patron of the Arts and Crafts Movement and the Gothic Revival style.

architects.name: Charles Barry
architects.description: Charles Barry was an English architect known for his work on the Palace of Westminster. He was a proponent of the Gothic Revival style in architecture, which he believed was a more appropriate style for the new Houses of Parliament than the original neoclassical design.

style.description: A style that originated in England and spread across Europe and North America, characterized by the use of ornamentation, pointed arches, vaults, and steeply pitched roofs to evoke a medieval past.
examples: St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City

Gothic Revival.terms: nouns: pointed arches, gargoyles, stained glass windows, buttresses, spires, tracery, spookinessadjectives: ornamental, medieval, dark, mysterious, dramatic, romantic, eerie

architects.name: Hector Guimard
architects.description: Hector Guimard was a French architect, designer and decorator who is famous for his Art Nouveau style.

architects.name: Victor Horta
architects.description: Victor Horta was a Belgian architect and designer who is famous for his Art Nouveau buildings and interior designs.
notableBuildings: House and Studio of Victor Horta

architects.name: Antoni Gaudí
architects.description: Antoni Gaudí was a Spanish architect and designer who is famous for his Art Nouveau buildings and unique style.

style.description: Art Nouveau is an artistic style that emerged in the late 19th century characterized by organic and curved lines, asymmetry, and the use of natural elements such as flowers, plants, and insects. It was a reaction against the academic art of the 19th century and aimed to create a new style that was modern and original.
characteristics: Natural elements such as flowers, plants, and insects
Use of new materials and techniques
examples: École de Nancy in Nancy, France

Art Nouveau.terms: architecture: decorative, ornate, elaborate, asymmetrical, organicfeatures: curved lines, floral motifs, stained glass windows, wrought ironwork, sinuous curvesinfluence: 19th century decorative arts, nature, Japanese artexamples: Hector Guimard's Paris Metro entrances, Victor Horta's Hotel Tassel in Brussels, Antoni Gaudi's Sagrada Familia in Barcelona.

architects.name: William Van Alen
architects.description: Master of Art Deco designs, popularized the use of stainless steel in architecture

architects.name: Erich Mendelsohn
architects.description: Known for designing dynamic, streamlined Art Deco buildings that combined technology, science, and modern industrial materials

architects.name: Timothy Pflueger
architects.description: Pioneered Art Deco architecture in San Francisco, blending classicism with modernism

style.description: Art Deco is a style that emerged in the 1920s and 1930s, and is characterized by bold geometric shapes, bright colors, and luxurious materials. It was influenced by various art movements, including Cubism and Futurism, and was seen as a celebration of modernity.
examples: Chrysler Building in New York City
The Daily Express Building in Manchester, UK
Radio City Music Hall in New York City
The Hoover Building in London, UK
The Empire State Building in New York City

Art Deco.terms: Art Deco architecture: geometric shapes, bold colors, luxurious materials, streamlined forms, symmetrical patterns, decorative motifs, plush interiors, lavish embellishments, glamorous aesthetics, modernist design.

architects.name: Le Corbusier
architects.description: One of the pioneers of modern architecture, Le Corbusier was also a painter, designer, and writer. He believed that architecture could improve the lives of people and society.

architects.name: Paul Rudolph
architects.description: Known for his use of concrete and his interest in modular building, Paul Rudolph was also trained as a musician and a painter.

architects.name: Alison and Peter Smithson
architects.description: A husband and wife duo, they were key figures in the brutalist movement in Britain, known for their use of concrete and their interest in the relationship between people and their environment.

style.description: Brutalism is an architectural style characterized by rough concrete surfaces, bold geometric shapes, and an overall monumental and austere appearance. It emerged in the mid-20th century as a response to the International Style and sought to express the true nature of raw materials in an honest and straightforward way.
characteristics: Heavy use of raw, unornamented concrete
examples: Smithsonian Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington D.C., USA
University of Pittsburgh Cathedral of Learning in Pittsburgh, USA

Brutalism.terms: Concrete, angular, functional, large-scale, monolithic, unornamented, linear, geometric. Brutal, stark, industrial, raw, austere, minimalistic, impersonal, oppressive, utilitarian.

architects.name: Robert Venturi
architects.description: An American architect and author regarded as one of the most influential figures in postmodern architecture. He played a major role in the development of the postmodernist movement with his 1966 book, Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture.
notable_buildings: National Museum of American Jewish History

architects.name: Philip Johnson
architects.description: An American architect best known for his works in postmodern architecture. He is one of the most renowned architects of the 20th century and played a major role in popularizing postmodern architecture through his influential buildings and writings.

architects.name: Michael Graves
architects.description: An American architect and designer renowned for his postmodernist architecture and product design. Graves was one of the leading figures of the postmodernist movement and his buildings are known for their playful and eclectic style.

style.description: Postmodern architecture is an eclectic style that emerged in the late 20th century. It is characterized by the use of playful forms, bright colors, and references to historical architectural styles and pop culture. Postmodernism rejects the strict rules of modernism and celebrates individualism and creativity.
examples: AT&T Building in New York City
Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles

Postmodernism.terms: movement, architecture, art, design, history, innovation, identity, diversity, deconstruction, pastiche, context, urbanism, consumerism, media, technology  eclectic, experimental, fragmented, self-referential, playful, ironic, subversive, non-linear, anti-establishment, contextual, inclusive, global, commercial, digital

architects.name: Frank Gehry
architects.description: Known for his use of unusual building materials and undulating forms
notable_buildings: Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles

architects.name: Zaha Hadid
architects.description: Known for her futuristic designs and use of complex geometric shapes

architects.name: Rem Koolhaas
architects.description: Known for his experimentation with form and materials

style.description: Deconstructivism is an architectural style or movement that rejects the traditional harmony, unity, and symmetry of architecture. It is characterized by irregular shapes, angles, and unexpected forms. The aim is to create visual complexity and confusion, challenging the viewer's perception of space. Deconstructivism can be seen as a reaction against the strict and rigorous modernism of the early 20th century.

Deconstructivism.terms: architecture, deconstruction, fragmentation, complexity, ambiguity, non-rectilinear shapes, angles, diagonal lines, interlocking spaces. non-linear, disorienting, angular, fragmented, complex, provocative, abstract.

architects.name: Zaha Hadid
architects.description: Hadid was known for her fluid, organic designs that often resembled natural forms. She was the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize.
notable_buildings: MAXXI National Museum of the 21st Century Arts

architects.name: Santiago Calatrava
architects.description: Calatrava's designs often involve flowing forms and structural elements that resemble the skeletons of animals. He is known for his use of white concrete and steel.

architects.name: Bjarke Ingels
architects.description: Ingels combines elements of classical architecture with modern technology to create designs that are both daring and functional. His buildings often incorporate sustainable materials and have unique shapes.

style.description: Neo-Futurism is a modern architectural style that combines futuristic concepts with avant-garde designs. It tries to convey a sense of optimism and a belief in progress through the use of advanced technology and unconventional materials.
characteristics: Use of organic and unconventional shapes
Use of advanced technology and modern materials
examples: The Dancing House in Czech Republic

Neo-Futurism.terms: Dynamic, asymmetrical, unconventional, innovative, sustainable, minimalistic, interactive, experiential, adaptable.

architects.name: Zaha Hadid
architects.description: Hadid is known for her futuristic designs and use of Parametricism. She was the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004.
notable_buildings: Heydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan

architects.name: Frank Gehry
architects.description: Gehry is known for his deconstructivist style and use of complex shapes and curves. He has won numerous awards for his work, including the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1989.
notable_buildings: Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles

architects.name: Bjarke Ingels
architects.description: Ingels is known for his environmentally conscious designs and use of Parametricism. He founded the architectural firm BIG (Bjarke Ingels Group) in 2005.
notable_buildings: 2 World Trade Center in New York City
Google North Bayshore Campus in Mountain View, California

style.description: Parametricism is a contemporary architectural style that utilizes digital technology to create complex and optimized architectural forms.
characteristics: Use of parametric computer software to design complex geometric forms
examples: Zaha Hadid's Galaxy SOHO in Beijing
Heatherwick Studio's Vessel in New York City

Parametricism.terms: Parametricism, architecture style innovative, adaptive, flexible, computational, digitized, organic, interconnected, complex, efficient, aesthetic

architects.name: Ernst Barlach
architects.description: A German expressionist sculptor, printmaker and writer famous for his protest against the war and his social and political sculpture.

architects.name: Hans Scharoun
architects.description: A German architect and urban planner who became famous for his work in Berlin in the 1950s and 1960s.

architects.name: Erich Mendelsohn
architects.description: A German architect who is known for his imaginative and innovative designs that were influenced by expressionism and the dynamic movement of objects.

style.description: Expressionism was a relatively short-lived architectural movement in Germany in the early 20th century. It was primarily an artistic movement, but its principles also found expression in architecture.
characteristics: Expressionist architecture is characterized by its dramatic shapes
as well as its use of unconventional materials like reinforced concrete. It is also known for its use of color and light
often employing stained glass to create vibrant

Expressionism.terms: Emotion, distortion, abstraction, angularity, vibrant colors, rawness, wood, brick, steel.

architects.name: John Thorpe
architects.description: One of the most important Tudor architects, known for his work on country houses and palaces.

architects.name: Robert Smythson
architects.description: A leading Elizabethan architect, known for his work on grand country houses and gardens.

architects.name: John Loughborough Pearson
architects.description: A Gothic Revival architect who designed many churches and cathedrals in Tudor style.

style.description: Tudor architecture is an architectural style which developed during the Tudor period in England between the late Medieval period and the early Renaissance. It is characterized by half-timbered buildings with exposed wood beams, ornate chimneys, and steeply pitched roofs. Tudor architecture is known for its symmetry, often featuring large, decorative chimneys on each end of the building, and large mullioned windows.

Tudor.terms: buildings, structures, palaces, mansions, churches, castles, houses, gardens ornate, symmetrical, asymmetrical, grand, dramatic, imposing, prestigious, historic, decorative, elaborate

architects.name: John Notman
architects.description: Considered the father of the Italianate style in America

architects.name: A. J. Downing
architects.description: Landscape designer and one of the leading proponents of the Italianate style in America
notable_buildings: Downing's own home, the Villa Mille Fleurs, on the Hudson River
The villa-style entrance to the U.S. Botanic Garden in Washington, D.C.

architects.name: Thomas S. Kirkbride
architects.description: Psychiatrist and advocate for humane treatment of the mentally ill, who designed several monumental Italianate-style hospital buildings
notable_buildings: The Trenton State Hospital, New Jersey
The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum, West Virginia

style.description: Italianate architecture is a style characterized by an emphasis on Italian Renaissance elements, such as tall towers, elaborate decorative brackets, and pedimented windows and doors. The style is often used in buildings such as public institutions, homes, and commercial buildings.
examples: William Watts Sherman House (Newport, Rhode Island)
Palace of Fine Arts (San Francisco, California)

Italianate.terms: Italianate architecture: style, popular, mid-19th century, United States and Europe, derived, Renaissance architecture, ornamental, decorative, flat roofs, wide eaves, brackets and cornices, symmetrical, towers, campaniles, arcaded windows, rounded arches, rusticated stonework, terraces.

architects.name: Konstantin Melnikov
architects.description: Melnikov was a leading Soviet Constructivist architect, known for his pioneering work in using modern materials such as reinforced concrete and glass.

architects.name: Moisei Ginzburg
architects.description: Ginzburg was a prominent Soviet architect and theorist, known for his contributions to the development of Constructivism and Rationalism.

architects.name: Ivan Leonidov
architects.description: Leonidov was a Soviet architect and artist, known for his innovative designs that combined elements of Constructivism, Futurism, and Surrealism.
notable_buildings: Pavilion of the USSR at the World's Fair in Paris

Constructivism.terms: unique spaces, sustainable materials, creative forms, contextual integration, user experience innovative, dynamic, holistic, human-centered, environmentally conscious

style.description: The use of simple geometric forms, clear lines, and utilitarian designs that rejected ornamentation and celebrated industrial materials and production techniques.
examples: Tatlin's Tower in St. Petersburg, Russia

architects.name: Unknown
architects.description: Neolithic builders were skilled in the use of mud, wood, and stone. They built structures to meet their needs and worship their gods.

architects.name: Dolmen builders
architects.description: Dolmen builders are known for their megalithic structures, which are a type of large stone monument.

architects.name: Mound Builders
architects.description: Mound builders created massive earthworks for various purposes, including ceremonial centers, burial mounds, and defensive structures.

style.description: The Neolithic architecture style refers to the buildings and structures constructed during the Neolithic period, which is also known as the New Stone Age. During this time, humans transitioned from a nomadic lifestyle to a more settled one, leading to the development of permanent structures and the advent of agriculture.
characteristics: Use of natural materials such as wood, stone, mud, and thatch
Roofs made of thatch or animal hides
Strictly functional design with little decoration
Incorporation of religious or spiritual symbols in some structures
Use of megaliths for ceremonies and burial sites

Neolithic.terms: adjectives: simple, functional, monumental, communalnouns: stone walls, mud bricks, thatched roofs, roundhouses, megalithic structures

architects.name: Yu Wenxiu
architects.description: Yu Wenxiu was a famous Chinese architect who was known for his expertise in the Chinese Imperial style of architecture.

architects.name: Li Jie
architects.description: Li Jie was a renowned architect during the Yuan and Ming dynasties in China. He contributed greatly to the Chinese Imperial style of architecture.

architects.name: I.M. Pei
architects.description: I.M. Pei was a renowned architect who contributed to the contemporary interpretation of Chinese Imperial style in architecture.

style.description: Chinese Imperial architecture style is characterized by its grandeur, intricate details, and strong emphasis on symmetry. It is influenced by traditional Chinese beliefs and philosophy, such as feng shui and the balance of yin and yang. The style also incorporates elements of Buddhist and Taoist architecture.
characteristics: Emphasis on grandeur and grandiose structures
Intricate detailing, often made from wood or stone
Use of bright colors and ornate decorations
Incorporation of elements of nature and traditional Chinese beliefs
Axial designs, with buildings often arranged around a central axis
examples: The Temple of Heaven in Beijing
The Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor in Shaanxi

Chinese Imperial.terms: Roof tiles, eaves, columns, courtyards, gardens, screens, pavilions, bridges, gateways.  Colorful, intricate, ornate, symmetric, grand, traditional, symbolic, spiritual.

architects.name: Frank Lloyd Wright
architects.description: Considered one of the greatest American architects, Wright is known for his organic architecture that emphasizes the relationship between buildings and nature.

architects.name: Mies van der Rohe
architects.description: A pioneer of modernist architecture, Mies van der Rohe is known for his minimalistic and functional designs that emphasize clean lines and industrial materials.

architects.name: Richard Neutra
architects.description: A leading figure in the mid-century modern movement, Neutra's designs reflect a blend of European modernism and California's landscape.

style.description: Mid-Century Modern is a style of architecture, interior design, and product design that originated in the mid-20th century. The style is characterized by clean lines, minimal ornamentation, and an emphasis on functionality. It emphasizes the use of natural materials such as wood and stone, as well as new materials such as plastic and fiberglass. The style is often associated with the post-World War II period, when there was a need for practical and affordable housing for the middle class.
characteristics: Use of natural and new materials
Integration of indoor and outdoor spaces
Large windows and ample natural light
examples: The Farnsworth House by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
The Eames House by Charles and Ray Eames
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum by Frank Lloyd Wright
The Seagram Building by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
The Stahl House by Pierre Koenig

Mid-Century Modern.terms: simplicity, function, minimalism, clean lines, open spaces.  sleek, futuristic, industrial, understated, angular.

architects.name: Hassan Fathy
architects.description: Known for his advocacy of mud brick architecture and for integrating traditional Egyptian building techniques with modern architectural principles.

architects.name: Nader Khalili
architects.description: Founder of the California Institute of Earth Art and Architecture, known for his work with adobe architecture and for developing Superadobe, a patented building system based on earthbag construction.

architects.name: Simone Swan
architects.description: Known for her work in sustainable architecture and for her advocacy of sustainable building materials such as mud brick and adobe.

style.description: Mud brick architecture is a traditional style of construction that uses mud or clay as the primary building material. It is prevalent in arid and semi-arid regions where mud is readily available and provides natural insulation against harsh climates.
characteristics: Heavy use of mud bricks as building blocks
Use of mud as mortar or plaster
Simple design with flat roofs and rounded corners
Decorative features such as wooden beams, plaster reliefs, and painted motifs
High thermal mass and energy efficiency
examples: The ancient city of Jericho in Palestine
The Great Mosque of Djenne in Mali
The city of Shibam in Yemen
The city of Mudhera in Sudan

Mud Brick.terms: architecture style, primitive, ancient, sustainable, mud-based, vernacular, low-tech, earthy, regional, organic, cyclical, renewable, community-oriented, traditional.
